definitions.definition: certain or likely to happen, or to do or be something

examples.text: There are bound to be changes when the new system is introduced.
It's bound to be sunny again tomorrow.
You've done so much work—you're bound to pass the exam.
It was bound to happen sooner or later *(= we should have expected it)*.
These problems were almost bound to arise.
You're bound to be nervous the first time *(= it's easy to understand)*.

definitions.definition: forced to do something by law, duty or a particular situation
definitions.sensetop: bound by somethingbound (by something) to do something

examples.text: We are not bound by the decision.
You are bound by the contract to pay before the end of the month.
I am **bound to say** I disagree with you on this point.
They are legally bound to appear in court.
He was legally bound to report them to the authorities.
Officials are bound by law to investigate any possible fraud.
The president said the country could not be held bound by a treaty signed by the previous regime.
We are legally bound by this decision.

definitions.definition: prevented from going somewhere or from working normally by the conditions mentioned

examples.text: Strike-bound travellers face long delays.
fogbound airports

definitions.definition: travelling, or ready to travel, in a particular direction or to a particular place

examples.text: homeward bound *(= going home)*
Paris-bound
**northbound/southbound/eastbound/westbound**
a plane bound for Dublin
tourists who are bound for Europe
college-bound high school students
communities bound together by customs and traditions

definitions.definition: very busy with something; very interested or involved in something

examples.text: He's too bound up in his work to have much time for his children.
I came here bound and determined to put the last 12 months behind me.
From that moment my life became inextricably bound up with hers.

definitions.definition: to feel that you must do something because of your sense of moral duty

examples.text: She felt honour-bound to attend as she had promised to.
He felt honour bound to help her.
They’re up to some mischief, I’ll be bound!

wordOrigin: adjective sense 4 Middle English boun (in the sense ‘ready, dressed’), from Old Norse búinn, past participle of búa ‘get ready’; the final -d is euphonic, or influenced by other adjective senses of bound.
